title: How to Tell the Difference Between a Milk Snake and a Coral Snake

steps.title: Check for stripes versus blotches.
steps.content: Check for stripes versus blotches. The differences in stripe patterns are typically used to tell the difference between milk and coral snakes. However, some milk snakes do not have stripes. If you notice a snake with blotches instead of stripes, it's more likely to be a milk snake. [1] X Research source However, do not assume a snake is not venomous simply because it has blotches. You should still stay away from a wild snake to avoid getting bitten.

steps.title: Look at whether black rings separate red and yellow rings.
steps.content: Look at whether black rings separate red and yellow rings. Both corral snakes and milk snakes contain black, yellow, and red splotches. With milk snakes, there will be a black ring between red and yellow rings. The red and yellow rings will not touch on a milk snake. [2] X Research source

steps.title: See if the red bands touch the yellow bands.
steps.content: See if the red bands touch the yellow bands. If red and yellow bands are touching, this is a bad sign, you are probably looking at a coral snake, which is venomous. You should stay away from snakes that have red and yellow stripes that touch. [3] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Be careful in areas with leaf piles or burrows. Coral snakes tend to hide in such areas.

steps.title: Examine the size of the snake.
steps.content: Examine the size of the snake. Milk snakes generally tend to be smaller than coral snakes. Most milk snakes are less than three feet long. However, if you live in Honduras, some milk snakes can grow as long as 5 feet in length. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Think about your own location.
steps.content: Think about your own location. Coral snakes are typically only found in three regions in the United States. Therefore, you're unlikely to find a coral snake if you don't live in those areas. [5] X Research source Coral snakes can live in Arizona and certain parts of Texas. Coral snakes can also live around Florida and its bordering states. Coral snakes may live in Florida, Georgia, Missouri, Alabama, South Carolina, and North Carolina.

steps.title: Look at the snake's face.
steps.content: Look at the snake's face. Coral snakes have a solid black face. There will be a yellow band directly below the solid black marking on the face. It may be difficult to see a coral snake's eyes due to the coloring on the face. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Be aware of the symptoms of snake bite.
steps.content: Be aware of the symptoms of snake bite. While you will usually be aware if a snake bites you, a young child or animal may not be able to tell you they were bitten. Make sure you know the symptom of a snake bite, especially if you live in an area that has poisonous snakes. Symptoms include: [7] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source A puncture wound with redness and swelling surrounding it Labored breathing Nausea or vomiting

steps.title: Seek medical attention immediately for a snake bite.
steps.content: Seek medical attention immediately for a snake bite. Even if you're not experiencing symptoms like pain or swelling, you should always seek medical help in the event of a snake bite. You should call 9-1-1 or the emergency services in your area. A worker should instruct you whether to come into the emergency room or make an appointment with your doctor as soon as possible. [8] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Do not attempt to treat the wound alone.
steps.content: Do not attempt to treat the wound alone. You should never attempt to make a tourniquet, slash the wound with a knife, or do any other treatments on your own. You should always seek out professional medical help in the event of a snake bite. [9] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Avoid attempting to trap the snake.
steps.content: Avoid attempting to trap the snake. Most snakes will not attack you unprovoked and are not dangerous, even if they are venomous. If your'e concerned about poisonous snakes in your area, contact animal control. Do not attempt to trap or kill a snake on your own. Not only can this be dangerous, it may be illegal in your area.
